prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Group 1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 6 mosaic observations of G010.8411, G012.9090 and G018.3412.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We use a spectral resolution of ~0.65km/s for the outflow/jet tracers and ~0.33 km/s for the envelope/disk tracers. These are chosen to ensure the high spectral resolution needed to fully resolve and quantify the kinematics of the line centre while also giving enough sensitivity to detect the outflow in the line wings. The bandwidth of the CO transitions is dictated by needing to have the 12CO, 13CO and C18O in one spectral setting and still cover the line wings with enough free channels to properly disentangle the continuum emission from the resulting spectra. As SiO often traces higher-velocity material than CO, a larger bandwidth is chosen for that line.
The continuum band is placed so as to avoid any strong lines. Spectral averaging has been used where appropriate to minimise the data rate.

The smallest angular scale (0.7") is chosen to allow us to probe similar or better spatial scales (<3000 AU) to single-dish observations of nearby, low-mass protostellar outflows (e.g. JCMT observations of the Perseus molecular cloud probe 3500 AU scales). It may also allow us to (marginally) resolve the SiO jets across their width in at least some of the source (e.g. the jet in IRAS17233 has a width of 1.4" at its narrowest, Klaassen et al., 2015, A&A, 575, 54). In addition, it will give us the best possible number of resolution elements both across and along the outflows without the need for more than one 12m configuration, thus giving the best balance of science vs. observing time.
The largest angular scale (60") is dictated by the angular scale of the outflows, which extend up to ~60" in the single-dish maps of high-velocity CO gas. We also use these data to select the regions to mosaic. In order to properly quantify how the outflow mass, momentum etc. vary along the outflow (derived from the 12CO, 13CO and C18O data), both mosaicing and the ACA are required.

We base our time calculation on detection of the C18O J=2-1 line, tracing the envelope/disk. The faintest peak C18O J-3-2 brightness temperature from JCMT observations towards these sources is 2.5K (Maud et al., subm.), with 12CO and 13CO considerably brighter over a larger extent. Even assuming that C18O emission fills the JCMT beam, and that C18O J=3-2 is the same brightness as C18O J=2-1 (both conservative assumptions), the C18O will be detected at 5 sigma or better in all sources with our sensitivity of 0.5K in ~0.33km/s channels. Such a sensitivity and channel width is required to accurately constrain the kinematics of the line (width, peak and shape).
For the outflow and jet tracers, 12CO and 13CO J=2-1 and SiO J=5-4, we are focused on the broad line wings, and so we spectrally average to ~0.65 km/s to reach a sensitivity of 0.35K. For 12CO and 13CO our single-dish data again suggests this is enough to detect the faintest outflow in the sample even if the emission fills the single-dish beam. For SiO J=5-4, this is also sufficient to detect the line at 2 sigma in even the faintest source (peak of 0.7K in SMA observations of G194.9349, Cunningham et al., in prep.) and considerably better in others (peak of >8K in IRAS 17233, Leurini et al., 2013, A&A, 554, 35).
For our secondary envelope/disk tracers, we retain the same velocity resolution and sensitivity as C18O 2-1. 13CS 5-4 is comparable or brighter than C18O 2-1 at the source centres (e.g. see the observations of G012.9090 of Galvin-Madrid et al., 2010, ApJ, 724, 17) and DCO+ should also be detected at the requested sensitivity (see e.g. Zinchenko et al., 2012, ApJ, 755, 177).
The continuum towards these sources is typically of order 100 mJy/beam converted to the requested beam size (e.g. Leurini et al., 2013, A&A, 554, 35, and Galvin-Madrid et al., 2010, ApJ, 724, 17). The faintest source for which we have a measured interferometric continuum flux (G194.9349, measured with the SMA, Cunningham et al., in prep.), has a peak of 3mJy/beam which results in a signal-to-noise of 35. Even in the unlikely event that the peak continuum flux is an order of magnitude lower, this will still give a better than 3 sigma detection. We have therefore quoted this value where previous interferometric observations are not available, to be ultra-conservative.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Group 2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 6 mosaic observations of G022.038 and G030.781.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Group 4
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 6 mosaics for G192.5843, G192.6005 and G194.9349.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Group 6
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 6 mosaics for G192.5843, G192.6005 and G194.9349.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
Outflows from young high-mass stars play an important role in their formation and influence the local star formation efficiency, but their driving mechanism and evolution are poorly understood. Scaling relations are found in outflow properties between low and high-mass YSOs using single-dish observations which, if fundamental, suggests a common driving mechanism and entrainment physics for all protostars. However, these data probe significantly different spatial scales from low to high mass so the relations may also be observational in origin.
We propose to map the confirmed outflows of 12 high-mass sources with D<4kpc, L from 3x10^3 to 1.5x10^5 Lsol and evolutionary stages from mid-IR dark to HII regions. We will constrain their driving mechanism from how outflow properties (e.g. morphology, collimation, mass, momentum) vary with distance from the powering source(s) and have the resolution and image fidelity to distinguish between individual and collective outflows. These observations will allow the first like-for-like comparison to single-dish observations of nearby low-mass outflows, enabling the origin of outflow property scaling relations to be revealed for the first time.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: Our most luminous source, G345.4938+01.4677, was also part of the successful, though currently unobserved, ALMA Cycle 2 proposal 2013.1.00489.S 'Are there disks around O-type protostars?' (PI R. Cesaroni). That proposal will be resubmitted for Cycle 3. The combination of the detailed, high resolution (0.2") disk properties from that program, if re-accepted and/or observed by ALMA and the outflow properties derived from the proposed observations will result in an unprecidented window into the links between disks and outflows in high-mass sources.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: This proposal is a re-working and resubmission of the Cycle 2 proposal 2013.1.00580.S 'Towards an evolutionary sequence for high mass protostellar outflows' (PI A. Chrysostomou). We have endevoured to take the TAC comments from the previous round into acount in refining our science goals, planned analysis and sample. In particular, we emphasise that even if the outflows from outflows have complex morphologies and properties which do not match any model, this is just as important and valid a result as finding that they match any of the currently proposed mechanisms.
